B. Race Conditions in Directory and File Handling (TOCTOU)

• Vulnerable Lines:

 – When deleting obsolete packages:

  (after obtaining the list from the localpkgs() function)
 
• Reason:
 The code performs “check‐then‐act” sequences without additional safeguards. For example, it first tests for directory existence (or a file’s presence) and then creates or deletes the directory/file. An attacker with the ability to modify (or inject a symlink in) the filesystem between the check and the act could trigger a race condition. This can lead to unintended file system modifications (such as deletion or even file creation in unexpected places) when an attacker sets up a symlink (or similar) between the call to os.path.exists and the subsequent os.makedirs or os.unlink.

──────────────────────────────

──────────────────────────────

The code is vulnerable mainly because it does not sanitize remote paths before joining them with a local directory (opening the door to directory traversal) and uses check‐then‐act patterns (TOCTOU) when making directories and deleting files. An attacker who can control parts of the repository metadata or the filesystem in the interim state could exploit these issues.

It is highly recommended to:
 – Validate and sanitize any external/path-derived strings;
 – Use safe methods (for example, canonicalizing paths and comparing against the intended base path) before performing file writes or deletions;

CVE Description: Hyperledger Indy Node is the server portion of a distributed ledger purpose-built for decentralized identity. In Hyperledger Indy before version 1.12.4, there is lack of signature verification on a specific transaction which enables an attacker to make certain unauthorized alterations to the ledger. Updating a DID with a nym transaction will be written to the ledger if neither ROLE or VERKEY are being changed, regardless of sender. A malicious DID with no particular role can ask an update for another DID (but cannot modify its verkey or role). This is bad because 1) Any DID can write a nym transaction to the ledger (i.e., any DID can spam the ledger with nym transactions), 2) Any DID can change any other DID's alias, 3) The update transaction modifies the ledger metadata associated with a DID.

If an attacker can control or spoof the notification (or if the endpoint accepts untrusted content), the code will make an outbound HTTP call to an arbitrary URL. This can lead to a server‐side request forgery (SSRF), allowing the attacker to induce requests to internal or sensitive endpoints.

• Certificate URL validation misconfiguration risk
 – Vulnerable lines: In the _get_cert_url() method (the block that checks if not cert_url.startswith("https://") and then iterates over settings.EVENT_CERT_DOMAINS)
 – Reason: Although the code performs some checks on the certificate URL—verifying it starts with “https://” and comparing the domain against entries in settings.EVENT_CERT_DOMAINS—the logic may be bypassed if the trusted domains are misconfigured. In particular, when a trusted domain contains “amazonaws.com,” the code first matches against a hard‐coded regular expression (SES_REGEX_CERT_URL). If that regex does not match and if the trusted domain splits into fewer than four parts the function returns None, but if it has four or more parts it only logs warnings and then later compares the tail of the netloc. A malicious actor might be able to supply a carefully crafted certificate URL that passes these loose checks if the settings are not “tight” or complete. This risk depends on proper configuration, so if settings.EVENT_CERT_DOMAINS is not configured as recommended the validation could be circumvented, leading to potential man‐in‐the‐middle attacks on signature verification.

3. If you have any further questions or need additional detail on any part of the analysis, please let me know.

– Other parts (like using SHA1 or recursive collection of bytes to sign) are by design reflecting the SNS specification and not directly exploitable in this context.
– The certificate caching mechanism and the use of third‐party libraries (cryptography, requests) shift the focus to how the incoming URLs and external data are validated. The two issues above, in particular the unvalidated SubscribeURL and the dependency on EVENT_CERT_DOMAINS configuration, are the most significant from a security perspective.
